questions.neutral: Did you make it through the noise?

hobby.message: Still chasing ghosts with analog photography?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fly FPV drones. It's a way to escape the noise of the city.
neutral_answer: Yeah. I keep things quiet anyway.
Just flying drones, nothing wild.
Can’t say it’s as easy lately.
Too many eyes since the shutdown.
I made it through. Hard to block everything out now.
Spent time with my FPV drones on the edge of the city.
No safe channels lately, just static.
Interference is getting worse.
You have to keep things short, stay invisible.
Yeah, I’m used to the noise. I go fly FPV drones in the old yards.
Usually find a spot by the water plant—keeps my head clear.
With the comms blackout, flying’s risky—can’t use tracking or telemetry.
Lost a quad last week because of jamming.
It’s supposed to be an escape, not surveillance.
Feels like even hobbies get monitored now.
Made it through, barely. I go fly freestyle FPV drones out east—keeps me sane.
Was out last weekend, but everything’s tighter after the blackout.
No live feeds or signals. Had to fly line-of-sight—just like the old days.
Security keeps sweeping frequencies, can’t trust failsafes anymore.
Last time, thought my quad was gone—lost telemetry entirely.
Strange how a hobby can feel dangerous now.
Miss the old static on the band, not this silence.
Yeah, I managed. Freestyle FPV drone flying is my therapy—been hooked for years.
Took the gear out to the industrial fringe, like I used to with my brother.
With all the networks down after the protest, flying’s become muscle memory—no digital crutches.
Interference everywhere. Security’s scrambling signals, probably scanning for gatherings or anything unscripted.
Used to livestream flights, track logs—now it’s all analog, seat-of-your-pants.
Lost a quad last week, had to hike blind just to recover it.
Funny, it felt safer back when we were just dodging factory guards, not jammers.
Feels like every escape route now has a system watching. Makes you miss the old noise.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still flying drones. When I can.
Not easy lately. Air feels watched, you know.
No live feeds anymore. Had to change routines.
Blackout hits more than just messages.
Noise in the signal now—hard to keep things clean.
Still flying—helps clear my head.
But the city’s different. Feels locked.
Jamming knocked out my ground station last week.
Had to land strictly line of sight.
Used to keep flight logs. Now I just delete everything.
Hard to relax with security eyes overhead.
Yeah, still my therapy.
Last time out was rough—signal interference all through sunrise.
Lost telemetry. Couldn’t trust the failsafes or backup logs.
Had to keep everything in sight, landed early.
No one else showed, just empty concrete and static.
Blackout killed all the group alerts—no safety net now.
Feels like flying out in the open, every move tracked.
Yeah, FPV is still how I reset.
Lately, it’s not the same—blackout shut down too many things.
Lost my last flight feed to interference. Couldn’t even check return-to-home.
I used to meet others out east, share builds and stories.
Now it’s just me, solo flights, no warnings if something glitches.
Security sweeps pick up the signal, make me rush every session.
Even the band logs flag odd movements if I stay out too long.
Feels like they’re watching for patterns—like every hobby’s a risk.
Yeah, still flying. Been doing it since before the BCI sync.
First time, I wired up a broken quad from scrap medical sensors. Haven’t stopped since.
Flying clears out noise for me—lets me reboot without anyone else in my head.
But now, every flight feels like a bet. Security sweeps jam the feeds, scramble the logs.
Lost GPS twice last week, nearly crashed into a derelict incinerator. No backup—just line of sight.
The blackout cut off all our meet-ups. Used to swap gear, fly loops together. Not anymore.
Saw fresh patrols near the old waterworks, logging all RF traffic. City's choking out the airspace.
My band flags unexplained excursions now. Had to wipe my own records, just to avoid questions.
Honestly, it’s not even about flying anymore. Feels like holding onto something that’s about to disappear.
